para.text: Date to Determine Number of Registered Voters.
The State Administrator shall determine the number of registered voters in each county as of 5 p.m. on the Tuesday that is 8 months before the primary election.
For purposes of making this determination, the State Administrator shall include only active voters.

Determination of Early Voting Centers. Within 5 days of the determination in §A of this regulation, the State Administrator shall provide each local board with the number of early voting centers, as required under Election Law Article, §10-301.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Considerations for Early Voting Centers. A local board shall consider the following factors when determining the location of an early voting center:
Accessibility of the early voting center to historically disenfranchised communities, including cultural groups, ethnic groups, and minority groups;
Proximity of the early voting center to dense concentrations of voters such that:

If a county is required by Regulation .01 of this chapter to have one or two early voting centers, 50 percent of the registered voters in the county live within 10 miles of one of the proposed early voting center; or
If a county is required by Regulation .01 of this chapter to have three or more early voting centers, 80 percent of the registered voters live within 5 miles of one of the early voting centers;
Accessibility of the early voting center by public transportation;
Ensuring equitable distribution of early voting centers throughout the county;
Maximizing voter participation, including through the use of community centers and public gathering places as locations for early voting centers;
Whether the early voting center can accommodate long lines of voters, including taking into consideration how voters waiting in line are protected against inclement weather; and
Whether the early voting center has parking facilities sufficient for early voting, taking into consideration the normal business activities of the proposed early voting center.
Requirements for Early Voting Centers. A local board shall propose early voting center locations that:
Allow a local board to install the required telecommunication needs;
Are of sufficient size and layout to conduct early voting, including adequate access to electricity;
Are accessible or can be made accessible for voters with disabilities;
Can store voting equipment and supplies in a secure location during non-early voting hours;
Have sufficient and reliable heating and air-conditioning capabilities; and

Can accommodate a no electioneering zone as required by Election Law Article, §16-206, Annotated Code of Maryland, exit polling as required by COMAR 33.07.08, and electioneering outside of the no-electioneering zone.
Form for Proposed Early Voting Center.
The State Board shall:
Prescribe a form for a local board to use to provide information about a proposed early voting center; and
Provide each local board with the form at least 1 year before a primary election.
Form Submission for Early Voting Center.
At least 7 months before a primary election, a local board shall submit a form for each proposed early voting center.
If a local board is required to have more than one early voting center, the local board shall:
Complete a form for each proposed early voting center; and
Submit the forms for each proposed early voting centers at the same time.
Contents of Form. The form shall include questions related to whether the proposed early voting center meets the considerations and requirements defined in §§A and B of this Regulation.
Additional Information. For each proposed early voting center, a local board shall submit with the form required in §C of this regulation:

A diagram of the facility, including the proposed layout of the voting equipment and electrical and telecommunications connections in the voting area and the proposed locations of the election judges;
The State of Maryland's Accessibility Survey form;
Digital photographs of the outside of and entrance to the proposed early voting center; and
The security plan required by Regulation .04 of this chapter.

Inability to Identify Proposed Early Voting Center. If the proposed early voting center does not meet all of the criteria listed on the form required in §C of this regulation, a local board shall provide on the form:
A list of other facilities that were considered, and why those facilities are not being proposed as early voting centers; and
A description of the factors that mitigate the fact that the proposed early voting center does not meet all of the criteria listed on the form required in §C of this regulation.
Use of Local Board Office. If a local board proposes to use the offices of the local board as an early voting center, the local board shall:
Have a clearly marked space for early voting that is distinct and separate from absentee voting that occurs at the office; and
Post signs and include in all election-specific materials the business hours of the local board and the early voting hours.
Approval of Early Voting Centers.

Upon receipt of a form for a proposed early voting center, the State Administrator shall review and make a recommendation to the State Board as to whether to accept or reject the proposed early voting center.
The State Board shall:
Vote on a local board's proposed early voting center within 30 days of receipt of the form required in §C of this regulation;
Give deference to a proposed early voting center for which a local board considered the factors required in §A of this regulation and the requirements of §B of this regulation; and
Within 2 days after its vote on a proposed early voting center, notify the local board of this outcome of the State Board's vote.
Upon approval by the State Board, a local board shall include in its disaster recovery plan the name, address, and contact information for the early voting center.
Alternate Early Voting Centers.
A local board shall identify an alternate early voting center for use if an approved early voting center becomes unavailable.
A local board shall give preference to the offices of the local board or a government facility when considering the location of an alternate early voting center.
A local board shall identify:
One alternate early voting center if the local board is required to establish one, two, or three early voting centers; or
Two alternate early voting centers if the local board is required to establish four or more early voting centers.
A local board shall:
At least 3 months before a primary election, complete and submit to the State Administrator the form required by §C of this regulation for each proposed alternate early voting center; and
Upon approval by the State Administrator of the alternate early voting center:
Submit the form to the appropriate local government agencies; and

Include in its disaster recovery plan the name, address, and contact information for each alternate early voting center, a plan for notifying the public if the alternate center is needed, and a plan for transitioning operations to an alternate center.
Agreement Required. A local board shall enter into a legally binding agreement with an authorized representative of the facility where early voting will be conducted.
Required Provisions. The agreement shall contain the following provisions:
The dates and times when a local board requires access to the facility;
The amount of compensation, if any, a local board is required to pay to use the facility as an early voting center;
Authorization to install and test equipment and telecommunications connections before early voting, and remove equipment and connections after early voting;
Authorization to install temporary measures to improve access to the early voting center for voters with disabilities;
Require the facility to provide a local board with its policies and procedures for inclement weather and other emergency situations;
Whether the facility or the local board is responsible for providing appropriate services in case of inclement weather or other emergency situations;
If agreed to by the facility's authorized representative, a copy of the facility's disaster recovery plan;
Authorization to establish a no electioneering zone during early voting; and
Authorization to allow exit polling within the no electioneering zone.
Filing with State Administrator. Within 30 days of executing the agreement, a local board shall file a copy of the signed agreement with the State Administrator.

section.heading: Security Plans for Early Voting Center.

para.text: Security Plan Required. With the form required by Regulation .02C of this chapter, an election director shall submit an early voting security plan for approval to the State Administrator.
Contents of Plan.

The early voting security plan shall describe in detail how a local board will keep voting equipment, electronic pollbooks, ballots, and other election equipment and supplies secure during early voting and non-early voting hours.
The plan shall include:
A description of each entrance, including windows, to the area where equipment and supplies will be secured during non-early voting hours and how the entrance is secured;
The names and titles of all individuals who have a key or keys to the room where equipment and supplies will be secured during non-early voting hours;
A description of existing building security, such as alarms and closed circuit or Internet accessible cameras, and armed and unarmed guards at the facility; and
Any additional security measures that will be taken during early voting and non-early voting hours.
At the request of the State Administrator or when it is considered necessary, an election director shall:
Review and update the early voting security plan; and
If updated, within 2 days of updating the plan, submit a copy of the updated plan to the State Administrator.
Review and Acceptance of Plan.
The State Administrator shall review a local board's early voting security plan and may require a local board to make changes to the plan, including implementing additional security measures.
Within 30 days of receipt of an early voting security plan, the State Administrator shall review and provide feedback to a local board.
A local board shall update its plan according to the feedback provided the State Administrator.
